monster.name: Belberith (Red Stalker)
languages: understands Abyssal but can't speak it

trait.name: Chameleon Carapace
entries: The belberith has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The bear has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) and Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The balor has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The balor's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Piercing Claws
entries: The belberith claw attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The belberith makes three melee attacks, but can use its bite only once.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage plus 16 ({@damage 3d10}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned}, the target falls {@condition prone} and is {@condition paralyzed}. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If it fails the initial or any subsequent saving throw by 5 or more, the target is reduced to 0 hit points.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) piercing damage. On a critical hit against a target wearing nonmagical armor or carrying a nonmagical shield, the belberith can destroy the nonmagical armor or nonmagical shield.

action.name: Web (3/Day)
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one Gargantuan or smaller creature. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} by webbing. As an action, the {@condition restrained} target can make a {@dc 16} Strength check, bursting the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 15; hp 5; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage), but a weapon that fails to destroy it becomes stuck, requiring a {@dc 16} Strength check to pull free.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The belberith's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Brute
entries: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the githyanki hits with it (included in the attack).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The githyanki can use its Aura of Ephelomon. It then makes three melee or ranged attacks.

action.name: Silver Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d6 + 8}) slashing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) psychic damage. This is a magic weapon attack. On a critical hit against a target in an astral body (as with the {@spell astral projection} spell), the githyanki can cut the silvery cord that tethers the target to its material body, instead of dealing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d64}) psychic damage.

action.name: Aura of Ephelomon
entries: Each creature of the githyanki's choice that is within 30 feet of the githyanki and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the githyanki's Aura of Ephelomon for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Breath of Ephelomon {@recharge 5}
entries: The githyanki exhales fire in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 56 ({@damage 18d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The githyanki's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The githyanki adds 5 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the githyanki must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon

trait.name: Fire of the Mind
entries: A target that fails a save against one of the githyanki's 1st level or higher fire spells becomes {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. While {@condition frightened}, the target also takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage at the start of each of its turns. At the end of each of its turns, the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw to end the effect.

trait.name: Sorcery Points
entries: The githyanki has 8 sorcery points. It can spend 1 or more sorcery points as a bonus action to gain one or both of the following benefits:

Careful Spell: When the githyanki casts a spell that forces other creatures to make a saving throw, it can protect some of those creatures from the spell's full force. To do so, it spends 1 sorcery point and chooses a number of those creatures up to it Charisma modifier. A chosen creature automatically succeeds on its saving throw against the spell.
Empowered Spell: When the githyanki rolls damage for a spell, it can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll a number of the damage dice up to its Charisma modifier. It must use the new rolls.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 2d4}) fire damage.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The githyanki's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The githyanki is a 8th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following sorcerer spells prepared:

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the Githyanki's darkvision.

trait.name: Disrupt Divinity
entries: Whenever the githyanki damages a creature that is concentrating on a divine spell, that creature has disadvantage on the Constitution saving throw it makes to maintain concentration. In addition, whenever the githyanki casts {@spell counterspell} to interrupt the casting of a divine spell, it rolls any ability check with advantage.

trait.name: Pact of the Lich-Queen
entries: When the githyanki deals psychic damage to a creature, the githyanki gains 5 temporary hit points and the creature can't regain hit points until the start of the githyanki's next turn.

trait.name: Psychic Sinkhole
entries: Any creature that enters or begins its turn within 5 feet of the githyanki can't take the Disengage action unless it makes a {@dc 16} Wisdom save. In addition, creatures within this area have disadvantage on death saves.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The githyanki attacks twice with its greatsword.

action.name: Silver Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage. This is a magic weapon attack. On a critical hit against a target in an astral body (as with the {@spell astral projection} spell), the githyanki can cut the silvery cord that tethers the target to its material body, instead of dealing damage.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The githyanki's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The githyanki is an 9th level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). It regains its expended spell slots when it finishes a short or long rest. It knows the following warlock spells:

reaction.name: Lightning Strike
entries: When a hostile crealure's movement provokes an opportunily attack, the githyanki can cast {@spell booming blade} and attack that creature as a reaction.

trait.name: Mental Dominator
entries: Targets have disadvantage on saving throws againsts this githyanki's {@spell charm person}, {@spell detect thoughts} and {@spell dominate person} spells.

trait.name: Unwitting Ally
entries: While the githyanki is within 5 feet of a target it has dominated, it has advantage on Dexterity and Wisdom ability checks and saving throws.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The githaynki deals an extra 14 ({@dice 4d6}) damage when it hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the githyanki that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and the githyanki doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Redirect Attack
entries: When a creature the githyanki can see targets it with an attack, the githyanki chooses a humanoid it has dominated within 5 feet of it. The two swap places, and the dominated humanoid becomes the target instead.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The githyanki's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the gnoll reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the gnoll can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make a bite attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gnoll makes two attacks, either with its spear or longbow, and uses its Reckless Barrage if it can.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage, and the target's speed is reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Reckless Barrage {@recharge 5}
entries: Up to three allied gnolls within 60 feet of it can each use their reactions to make a ranged attack with disadvantage if they can hear the gnoll and have the Rampage trait.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: If the gnoll sees a conscious creature that takes damage and has 10 hit points or fewer, it can use its reaction to make a ranged attack against that creature.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the gnoll hits with it (included in its attacks).

trait.name: Fateful Aura
entries: Any creature within 15 feet of the gnoll has disadvantage on death saving throws.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the gnoll reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the gnoll can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make a bite attack.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the gnoll can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Warmonger
entries: Any hostile creature within 5 feet of this gnoll has disadvantage on attack rolls against targets that don't have this trait or one similar to it. An enemy is immune to this effect if it can't see or hear this gnoll or if it can't be {@condition frightened}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gnoll makes two attacks with its battleaxe.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) slashing damage, or 6 ({@damage 2d10 + 3}) slashing damage when used with two hands to make a melee attack.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The gnoll has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all of its hit points.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the gnoll reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the gnoll can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make a bite attack.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the gnoll takes 15 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hit points, it is reduced to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gnoll makes two attacks: one with its greataxe and one with its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Greataxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d12 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Yeenoghu's Feast
entries: The gnoll feasts on the corpse of one intelligent creature within 5 feet of it that it has killed within the past minute. The gnoll immediately recharges Relentless, gains 10 ({@dice 3d6}) temporary hit points and has advantage on its next melee attack.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the gnoll reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the gnoll can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make a bite attack.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the gnoll reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the gnoll can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make a bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Quarterstaff (Gnoll Form Only).
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage, or 4 ({@damage 1d8}) bludgeoning damage if wielded with two hands.

action.name: Change Shape (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The gnoll magically polymorphs into a hyena, remaining in that form for up to 3 hours. It can revert to its true form as a bonus action. Its statistics, other than its speed, are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed by the new form. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

reaction.name: Cursed Wound
entries: When an ally hits a creature with a melee attack, the gnoll curses the wound, provided the creature is visible to the gnoll and within 60 feet. The target is cursed until the end of its next turn. While cursed in this way, its speed is halved, and it has disadvantage on its next attack roll.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting (Gnoll Form Only)
headerEntries: The gnoll is a 5th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 12}, {@hit 4} to hit with spell attacks). The gnoll has the following druid spells prepared:

spells: {@spell conjure animals} (hyenas or giant hyenas only)

trait.name: Cackle Fever Carrier
entries: After {@dice 1d4} hours, any creature damaged by a rot-walker must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or contract a disease. A diseased creature gains a level of {@condition exhaustion} that can't be removed until the disease is cured.

Any event that causes the infected creature great stress—including entering combat, taking damage, experiencing fear or having a nightmare—forces the creature to make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) psychic damage and becomes {@condition incapacitated} with hyena-like cackling for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the cackling and the {@condition incapacitated} condition on a success.

Any humanoid creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of an infected creature in the midst of cackling must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or also become diseased. Once a creature succeeds on this save, it is immune to the hyena-like cackling of that particular diseased creature for 24 hours.

At the end of each long rest, a diseased creature can make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. On a successful save, the DC for this save and for the save to avoid an attack of hyena-like cackling drops by {@dice 1d6}. When the saving throw DC drops to 0, the creature recovers from the disease. A creature that fails three of these saving throws may gain a randomly determined form of indefinite madness, as described in the Dungeon Master's Guide.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the gnoll reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the gnoll can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make a bite attack.

trait.name: Undead Fortitude
entries: If damage reduces the rot-walker to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the rotwalker drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The rot-walker makes two attacks with its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Sudden Rush
entries: Until the end of the turn, the rot-walker's speed increases by 40 feet.

trait.name: Wary Hunter
entries: The gnoll and up to one ally within 60 feet have advantage on Wisdom (Perception), Dexterity (Stealth) and Wisdom (Survival) checks, provided that they are both proficient in the skill used and are aware of each other.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the gnoll reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the gnoll can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make a bite attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gnoll makes two attacks, either with its spear or longbow.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage, and the target's speed is reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.

reaction.name: Warning Yelp
entries: When the gnoll is damaged (and not reduced to 0 hit points), it howls loud enough to be easily heard by creatures up to 600 feet away.

monster.name: Hellseeker
languages: understands Abyssal and Infernal but can't speak

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The hellseeker regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the hellseeker takes radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the hellseeker's turn. The hellseeker dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The hellseeker's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Unerring Tracker
entries: The hellseeker is given a quarry by its summoner. The hellseeker knows the direction and distance to its quarry, even if it's on a different plane of existence. The hellseeker also knows the location of its summoner. If the creature being tracked dies or the object is destroyed, the hellseeker knows.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hellseeker makes four cleaver claw attacks and one eye ray or bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until the grapple ends, the hellseeker can bite only the {@condition grappled} creature and has advantage on attacks rolls to do so. While {@condition grappled}, the creature has disadvantage on saving throws against the hellseeker's eye ray attacks.

action.name: Cleaver Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) slashing damage. If the hellseeker hits with two of its cleaver claws, it has advantage on its bite attack.

action.name: Eye Ray
entries: The hellseeker uses one of its magical eye rays, choosing a target that it can see within 90 feet of it for all but the lightning ray. Each eye ray can only be used once every four rounds:

Fireburst Ray. The hellseeker creates a fiery mote that explodes at a point it can see within 90 feet of it. Each creature in a 5-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 42 ({@damage 10d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Ice Ray. The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 42 ({@damage 10d6}) cold damage and its speed becomes 0 and it can't take reactions until the end of its next turn. On a successful save it only takes half the cold damage.

Lightning Ray. The hellseeker fires a line of lightning that is 60 feet long and five feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 42 ({@damage 10d6}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Petrification Ray. The targeted creature must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature begins to turn to stone and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is {@condition petrified} until freed by the {@spell greater restoration} spell or other magic.

trait.name: Amorphous (Ooze Form Only)
entries: The oozeworm can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Corrosive Form
entries: A creature that touches the oozeworm or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) acid damage. Any nonmagical weapon made of metal or wood that hits the oozeworm corrodes. After dealing damage, the weapon takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to −5, the weapon is destroyed. Nonmagical ammunition made of metal or wood that hits the oozeworm is destroyed after dealing damage. The oozeworm can eat through 2-inch-thick, nonmagical wood or metal in 1 round.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The oozeworm can use its action to polymorph into a worm form or back into its ooze form. The worm form appears as a unctuous, slug-like worm with several feeble-looking tentacles ringing a sharp grick-like beak. Its statistics are the same in each form, except in worm form it gains a burrow speed. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its ooze form if it dies.

trait.name: Spider Climb (Ooze Form Only)
entries: The oozeworm can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Psionic Saturation
entries: The oozeworm's proficiency bonus is doubled when determining the save DC for its innate spellcasting and tentacle and mind blast actions.

action.name: Multiattack (Worm Form Only)
entries: The oozeworm makes four melee attacks, but can use its bite only once.

action.name: Bite (Worm Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Pseudopod (Ooze Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) acid damage. In addition, nonmagical armor worn by the target is partly dissolved and takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to the AC it offers. The armor is destroyed if the penalty reduces its AC to 10.

action.name: Tentacle (Worm Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) psychic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Mind Blast (1/Day)
entries: The oozeworm magically emits psychic energy in a 30-foot radius. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 16} Intelligence saving throw or take 18 ({@damage 4d8}) psychic damage and be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionic)
headerEntries: The oozeworm's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 16}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

monster.name: Slitherslime
senses: blindsight 60 ft. (darkvision 90 ft. in serpent form)

trait.name: Amorphous (Ooze Form Only)
entries: The slitherslime can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Corrosive Form
entries: A creature that touches the slitherslime or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) acid damage. Any nonmagical weapon made of metal or wood that hits the slitherslime corrodes. After dealing damage, the weapon takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to −5, the weapon is destroyed. Nonmagical ammunition made of metal or wood that hits the oozeworm is destroyed after dealing damage. The slitherslime can eat through 2-inch-thick, nonmagical wood or metal in 1 round.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The slitherslime can use its action to polymorph into a serpent form or back into its ooze form. The serpent form appears as a thickbodied, scaled snake with four muscular arms protruding from near its head. Its statistics are the same in each form, except in serpent form it gains a burrow speed and darkvision. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its ooze form if it dies.

trait.name: Spider Climb (Ooze Form Only)
entries: The slitherslime can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Psionic Saturation
entries: The slitherslime's proficiency bonus is doubled when determining the save DC for its innate spellcasting and tentacle and mind blast actions.

action.name: Multiattack (Serpent Form Only)
entries: The slitherslime makes four melee attacks, but can use its bite and constrict attacks only once each.

action.name: Bite (Serpent Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Claw (Serpent Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 3d4 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Constrict (Serpent Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage plus 9 ({@dice 2d8}) and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the slitherslime can't constrict another target.

action.name: Pseudopod (Ooze Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) acid damage. In addition, nonmagical armor worn by the target is partly dissolved and takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to the AC it offers. The armor is destroyed if the penalty reduces its AC to 10.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The slitherslime's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 16}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

monster.name: Penanggalan
languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Horrifying Visage
entries: Each living creature within 60 feet of the penanggalan that can see her must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if the penanggalan is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to the penanggalan's Horrifying Visage for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Penanggalan Weaknesses
entries: The penanggalan has the following flaws while separated from its body:
{@i Reattach.} After sunrise, if the penanggalan cannot reattach its head to its body, it takes 30 radiant damage every hour that passes.
{@i Sunlight Paralysis.} The vampire takes 20 acid damage if it ends its turn in running water.

{@i Dense Vegetation.} Moving through any difficult terrain created by vegetation is harmful to the penanaggalan. Every 5 feet it travels, it takes 5 ({@dice 1d10}) piercing and slashing damage. It also has disadvantage on any saving throw or ability check to avoid or escape the effects of the vegetation.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: The penanggalan can use its action to polymorph into an ooze or back into its true form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed by the new form. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

While in ooze form, the penanggalan can't speak, fly, charm or attack and it loses its horrifying visage trait. It gains the ability to move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing (amorphous trait), its speed is 10 ft., and it gains blindsight 60 ft. Otherwise, the penanggalan's game statistics are unchanged.

trait.name: Walk as the Living
entries: When the penanggalan's head reattaches to its body, it appears as it did in life and its alignment is perceived as neutral. Also, it is unaffected by spells or magic that target or detect undead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Multiattack. The penanggalan makes two melee attacks, only one of which can be its bite

action.name: Withering Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one willing, {@condition incapacitated}, {@condition paralyzed} or {@condition restrained} creature. {@h}13 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. The penanggalan regains hit points equal to the necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be affected by a blood curse. A {@spell protection from evil and good} or similar spell will prevent this curse. The cursed target can't regain hit points, and its hit point maximum decreases by 10 ({@dice 3d6}) for every 24 hours that elapses. The curse lasts until it is lifted by a {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic. If the curse reduces the target's hit point maximum to 0, the target dies. If the target is a humanoid or giant and is buried without precautions, it will rise the following night as a ghoul under the penanggalan's control.

action.name: Entrails.
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 50 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target is {@condition paralyzed}, and ittakes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage at the start of each of its turns. The {@condition poisoned} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Emptying a vial of holy water on the target also ends the effect on it.

action.name: Slumber Charm (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The penanggalan targets one unconcious creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition charmed} for 10 minutes. While {@condition charmed} in this way, the target remains {@condition unconscious}, even when damaged. The effect will end earlier if the sunrises or the penanggalan is destroyed, is on a different plane of existence than the target or takes a bonus action to end the effect. If the target succeeds on its save, it is immune to the penanggalan's charm ability until sunrise, but does not awaken and is unaware of the charm attempt.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The penanggalan's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

variant.name: Crippling Blood Curse
entries: Instead of reducing the hit point maximum of its target, the resulting blood curse from the penanggalan's Withering Bite causes a level of {@condition exhaustion} for every 24 hours that elapse.

monster.name: Vampiric Mist
languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Blood Sense
entries: The mist can sense the location of any creature within 60 feet of it, unless that creature's type is construct or undead.

trait.name: Misty Form
entries: The thirsting death can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can pass through any space that isn't airtight and has advantage on Strength, Dexterity and Constitution saving throws.

trait.name: Misty Stealth
entries: The thirsting death can attempt to hide with advantage when only lightly obscured by darkness, fog, rain, falling snow or other similar phenomena.

trait.name: Satiated
entries: After a creature fails its saving throw against the engulf action, the thirsting death becomes thicker until it finishes a short rest. While satiated, its armor class is 16, its fly speed is 20 feet and it loses its misty stealth trait.

trait.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
entries: The thirsting death takes 20 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on ability checks.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The thirsting death moves up to its speed and can enter Large or smaller creatures' spaces. If the thirsting death ends its turn in the space of a creature with blood, the creature must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. If the creature has half its hit points or fewer, it makes the saving throw with disadvantage. On a failed save, the creature takes 18 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) necrotic damage and is {@condition poisoned} until the end of the thirsting death's next turn. The {@condition poisoned} creature can't breath, can't speak and is {@condition incapacitated}. On a successful save, the creature takes only half damage and isn't {@condition poisoned}.

The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken, and the thirsting death regains hit points equal to that amount. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

monster.name: Undying Heresy

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't silvered

languages: understands all languages it knew in life but doesn't speak

trait.name: Beget Anticreed (1/day)
entries: The heresy creates 4 ({@dice 2d4}) anticreeds per century it has existed. If an anticreed is destroyed, it reforms after the next sunset.

trait.name: Ephemeral
entries: The heresy can't wear or carry anything.

trait.name: Passive Target
entries: The heresy is effectively {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Limited Turn Resistance
entries: The heresy has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns undead. If it is successfully turned, it is destroyed.

trait.name: Profane Aura
entries: Abominable thoughts emanate from the heresy, spreading out 100 feet for every century it has existed. The aura isn't blocked by physical substances such as bricks, metals or water. When a creature starts its turn inside the aura, it must make a {@dc 16} Intelligence saving throw or be overwhelmed for 1 minute. An overwhelmed creature must spend its action giving voice to the foul philosophies of the heresy. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target attacks the nearest non-undead creature in a fit of nihilistic rage. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the start of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the aura for 1 hour.

trait.name: Execrating Tempest
entries: A dreadful, brooding storm spreads out 30 feet from the heresy, heavily obscuring it and affecting every creature except its anticreeds. Speed is halved in the area, and when a creature enters for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a {@dc 16} Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 18 ({@dice 4d8}) psychic and 18 ({@damage 4d8}) necrotic damage. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage.

trait.name: Vile Detritus
entries: When destroyed, the heresy screams in terror and bursts apart, leaving spectral remnants of its dark contemplations. A creature seeing or hearing this must succeed on a {@dc 16} Intelligence saving throw or be cursed. The cursed creature has disadvantage on Intelligence and Wisdom saving throws and all ability checks. The curse lasts until it is lifted by a remove curse spell of similar magic.

variant.name: Undying Atrocity
entries: Some heresies cause more than physical damage, the dreadful nature of their knowledge inflicts madness (see the Dungeon Master's Guide). An undying atrocity uses the undying heresy stat block, with the following changes:

items: Its Profane Aura trait is replaced with Aura of Madness (described below).
Its Vile Detritus reaction is replaced with Blasphemous Detritus (described below).

entries.name: Aura of Madness.
entries: Disturbing theories emanate from the atrocity, spreading out 100 feet for every century it has existed. The aura is not blocked by any physical substance such as bricks, metal or water. When a creature starts its turn inside the aura, it must make a {@dc 16} Intelligence saving throw or be afflicted with long-term madness until it finishes a short rest outside the aura. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the aura for 1 hour

entries.name: Summon Yugoloth (1/Day)
entries: When destroyed, the atrocity screams in terror and bursts apart, leaving spectral remnants of its foul doctrine. A creature seeing or hearing this must succeed on a {@dc 16} Intelligence saving throw or be afflicted with indefinite madness. The madness lasts until it is lifted by a greater restoration spell of similar magic.

monster.name: Anticreed
languages: understands all languages that the undying heresy knew in life but does not speak

trait.name: Bound Wanderings
entries: The anticreed can't move beyond the heresy's profane aura.

trait.name: Child of Heresy
entries: The anticreed doubles its proficiency bonus on the saving throw DC for its actions, but is destroyed if its heresy is destroyed.

trait.name: Ephemeral
entries: The anticreed can't wear or carry anything.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The anticreed doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The anticreed can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Turn Immunity
entries: The anticreed is immune to effects that turn undead.

trait.name: Momentary Clarity
entries: When a creature destroys the anticreed, it tears a brief hole in the aura of execration and gains an insight into the location of the heresy or a useful fragment of its knowledge.

action.name: Disturbing Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) necrotic damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) psychic damage.

action.name: Vile Curse (1/day)
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) necrotic damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) psychic damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence saving throw or be magically cursed for 24 hours. While cursed, the creature has disadvantage on saving throws and all ability checks related to an ability score of the DM's choice.

variant.name: Raving Anticreed
entries: The anticreed offspring of an undying atrocity also inflict madness (see the Dungeon Master's Guide). A raving anticreed uses the anticreed stat block, with the following changes:

items: Its Vile Curse action is replaced with Maddening Curse (described below).

entries.name: Touch of Madness (1/day)
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) necrotic damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) psychic damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence saving throw or be afflicted with short-term madness for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the start of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
Also known as the red stalkers, belberiths are enormous, predatory, arachnid-demons that even hunt their own kind.

entries.name: Butcher of Butchers
entries: Cruel, unwavring harbingers of death and torture, belberiths are hideous, misshapen spiderlike fiends with hard, chitinous shells. They have bodies the size of a war horse, fang-filled mouths that drip deadly venom, and all of it carried on legs a dozen feet tall.

entries.name: Eager for Blood
entries: A belberith usually picks one target and concentrate all of its attacks on it. Should a belberith become overwhelmed, it bites one last victim as it retreats via its plane shift ability and lets its poison to do the work

entries.name: Inscrutable Tormentors
entries: Belberiths prey on, or by some accounts punish, demons. They seem to select, by unknown means, groups of demons and exterminate them completely. Of equal mystery is how a demon, one of the cruelest and most chaotic creatures in existence, incurs their wrath.
Although creatures roam the Abyss that could destroy a belberith, nothing ever does. Belberiths have developed an uncanny mystique: among demons, destroying one is taboo.

entries.name: Butcher of Butchers
entries: Mages and alchemists pay extraordinary prices for belberith spinnerets. They believe, and with some justification, that the spinnerets are efficacious components in powerful spells and magical items of binding

entries.name: Ancient Alliance
entries: When the legendary Gith made a pact with Tiamat and Ephelomon, Tiamat's red dragon consort, the githyanki were given the Scepter of Ephelomon and red dragon allies. The proud dragons would serve the githyanki as mounts in exchange for the githyanki aiding Tiamat whenever she called upon them. Vlaakith I, whom Gith had designated as her successor, received the magical scepter and each githyanki queen has wielded it and controlled the red dragons under its dominion ever since.

Over the eons since the githyanki formed their pact with the Queen of Evil Dragons, their knowledge of their allies have only increased. Several githyanki queens have experimented with ways to leverage this for additional power. Based on these experiments and centuries of study, the Lich-Queen, Vlaakith the CLVII, leveraged the power of the scepter and created the duthka'gith, powerful githyanki warriors infused with the blood of red dragons. More powerful than a simple hybrid or hlaf-dragon, they were crafted with the power of the Nine Hells. These soldiers, though limited in number, pleased Vlaakith so much that they now serve her as her personal guard or as shock troops for particularly important missions.

Whether it is simply a gift from Tiamat or the result of a red dragon bloodline, githyanki flameweavers are pyrokenetic masters. The flames that they conjure don't just scorch the body, but the mind as well. The pain and fear from their attacks can last long after the flames have been extinguished. This power and the simple ability to reduce their enemies to ashes means that flameweavers are often arrogant. It's usually justified.

Githyuanki lichblades have made a soul-pact with the Lich-Queen to help her obtain her goal of becoming a god. This connection makes lichblades the closest thing that the githyanki have to a priestly warrior, providing spells and strengthening them in battle. It also gives them status to go wherever they please. They can join any gathering or accompany any githyanki raiding party, acting as the eyes and ears of the Lich-Queen

entries.name: Iconoclast
entries: However, their powers aren't limited to simple spells and social standing. The soul-pact allows them to feed the Lich-Queen's hunger for power. Lichblades are wreathed in a frightful void that consumes the souls of the fallen (friend and foe alike) and shattered divine magic. This is why they hunger for slaughter and will go out of their way to target those that use divine magic. Disrupting divine spells and slaying religious devotees are the greatest sacrifices they can offer their queen.

entries.name: Too Close
entries: Their role and powers make them universally feared amongst their kin. Standing next to a lichblade is almost universally avoided. All know that dying next to one is a terrible fate. The soul travels to Tu'narath, where the Lich-Queen awaits and souls are not free to return. Unfortunatelyfor githyanki, that's a fate that awaits them anyway.

While not as martially potent as githyanki knights, githyanki mindraiders are versatile servants for the the Lich-Queen. They invest little time in learning the ways of a warrior and focus primarily on sharpening their psionic powers to access the minds of foes. As a result, they're just as likely to act as spies and courtroom manipulators as lead ruthless incursions to steal resources.

entries.name: Grim Harvest
entries: Mindraiders are especially adept at making quick strikes into the Prime Material to gather slaves. Small warbands have been known to depopulate towns or, given enough time, entire regions. However, before starting a fullfledged raid, they scout out their target by dominating a local to examine the defenses and probe for weaknesses.

entries.name: Odd Couple
entries: Githyanki mindraiders gain significant advantages when paired with a dominated humanoid. The second set of eyes makes them harder to surprise, and the risk of harming an innocent is a powerful defense against would be heroes. This is why whenever they enter combat they have a dominated slave by their side -- or they quickly acquire one!

entries.name: Leader of the Pack
entries: Some assume that leadership of gnoll war bands is gained by sacrificing victims on an altar. However, champions of slaughter don't gain stature by dispatching helpless victims tied to an altar. Methodical preparation and somber violence would shame the Lord of Savagery. Proper sacrifices are made during the brutal, blood-soaked orgies that the ignorant simply call 'gnoll raids'.

The gnoll huntmaster is second only to the pack lord. It leads the hunters and scouts and is responsible for finding the pack's next target. Since this is the essential desire of the pack and ensures its survival, it's not uncommon for the most clever and skilled--if not the strongest and most martially adept--gnoll in the entire war band to fill this role. All huntmasters are skilled with their bow, picking off wounded prey, and rarely entering melee. As a result, these cunning gnolls usually live twice as long as most pack lords.

entries.name: Blame Game
entries: Before departing on an expedition, the huntmaster will consult with a fang of Yeenoghu or whichever shaman is in charge of interpreting the omens. That way, if an undefended village or caravan is not found, the huntmaster can deflect blame, which could bring death, and point its finger at those that gave it poor guidance.

Gnolls that are esepcially eager to prove themselves to Yeenoghu and their pack take an oath of slaughter, pledging to cause a worthy amount of bloodshed in the name of their lord. Each gnoll deathpledge (sometimes simply called a 'slayer') is then endowed with an unholy aura and attacks that sunder bone and flesh. Whether a gnoll fulfills its pledge or not determines whether it rises in status or is reviled and punished by the pack.

entries.name: Social Climber
entries: This mobility in the pack's hierarchy can cause swift changes to the pecking order, even at the top. For, if a pack lord fails to deliver enough butchery to please Yeenoghu, the most successful deathpledge steps forward as a challenger. No matter the outcome, the Lord of Slaughter is pleased.

To become a gnoll goreface, a veteran of several raids must be chosen by a fang of Yeenoghu or shaman and painted with crude runes or granted a grizzly talisman. This ritual changes the hunger that drives all gnolls into a literal madness.

entries.name: Always Hungry
entries: Gorefaces are so overcome with bloodlust that they'll often gorge on fallen foes in the middle of combat. Contrary to what one would expect, this actually prolongs their ability to butcher. Yeenoghu rewards them--somehow making them implacable, propelling them along a ceaseless pilgrimage of carnage. If someone repeatedly deprives them of this, even another gnoll, they'll make it their next victim.

No gnoll chooses to become a gnoll mangeheart, often just referred to as shaman. Instead, Yeenoghu chooses mangehearts from the wounded and maimed. Promising gnolls are mended just enough that they aren't ripped apart by their pack mates. Then Yeenoghu gifts them with the ability to take the form of a hyena so that they're able to keep up with the war band and serve as furtive spies. Yet, no matter their form, they retain some outward sign of their injuries, a limp, missing ear or severe scarring. They're almost always accompanied by one or more hyenas, which are their only companions and assist with scouting.

entries.name: Early Retirement
entries: Regardless, gone are their days of wanton butchery, hewing victims in two with mighty axes. Instead, mangehearts must be content with conducting rituals that invest warriors with the Slaughter Lord's power, raise up rot-walkers and witherlings, and weaken foes for others to cut down. If gnolls were any other creature, they might look upon mangehearts with pity. Instead, they see a weakling that's one wrong step away from becoming a meal.
It's a rule that maimed or dead gnolls don't last long. Surviving pack members devour their flesh and preserve the bones to use in rituals to create witherlings.

Similarly, it's also true that gnolls warbands don't attack fortified positions, opting for softer targets. Yet, sometimes Yeenoghu needs to shatter strongholds to open up an entire region to his rampaging reavers. And sometimes, he's just bored. At these times, the Ruler of Ruin and Rot sends omens and signs.

entries.name: Last Laugh
entries: The fangs of Yeenoghu and the mangehearts watch for portents when their warband is near a castle or walled town. If enemy shields shatter or slain gnolls putrify before eaten, they set aside the corpses. That night, they conduct a dark ritual, animating the dead which Yeenoghu blesses with a different weapon: disease. These blighted zombies are called 'rot-walkers' and carry cackle fever. The disease is so potent that even a small incursion at the outskirts of a town can seal the fate of its castle's garrison. Inevitably, a few wounded outrun the rot-walkers, fleeing to saftey. But once inside the walls, they begin to cough... cough and cackle. Soon, a third or more of the defenders are ill or dying. That's when the pack lord lets loose the war band. What was once impenetrable, now becomes an open feast with the weak and dead serving as garnish.

Even though gnolls aren't known for cooperation, gnoll scouts are very good at picking up on cues and signals from other pack members. As a result, gnolls always scout in pairs and are much more skilled as a result.

Pack lords and huntmasters send scouts out far and wide to track elusive prey, spot caravans or find poorly defended populations. When they find a promising target, one of the pair rushes back to alert the war band. The other might actually be patient enough to wait. During the resulting bloodletting, a gnoll scout will usually hang back a little to get a better view of the battlefield and pick off those that flee.

Hellseekers are crafted using foul sorcery known only to Yugoloth lords--some point to Bubonix--and the remains of slain fiends. Hired out as servants to the powerful and foolish, they specialize in retrieving objects and enemies.

entries.name: Obedience at a Price
entries: Their unwavering determination makes hellseekers valuable (and expensive) fiends to summon. The requisite ritual temporarily binds a hellseeker to the summoner. During this time, it relentlessly pursues commands until it completes them or is destroyed.

entries.name: Knockoff
entries: It's thought that the hellseeker was modeled after the belberith; there are similarities: a surprisingly quick, elephant-sized spider, with a thick carapace and multiple gem-like eyes. (Four eyes are smaller and capable of producing devastating magical rays.) The hellseeker's four rearmost limbs carry all its weight. The front four end in cleaver-like blades, which aren't for walking. The hellseeker's mandibles and fangs look terrifying, but usually just collect what it was sent to fetch.

Oozes are porous, absorbing nearly everything they come into contact with. This also seems to apply to psionic emanations, which can result in bizarre mutations. Because of this, there are a variety oozes that have gained psionic abilities. Broadly known as psionic oozes, those that develop talents complimenting their protean form--most notably, metamorphosis into creatures similar to those with potent psionic powers--are known as mutable oozes.

entries.name: Hunter-Gatherer
entries: Whatever the source of their mutation, mutable oozes usually wait for prey, hidden on rocky ledges, on dark cavern ceilings, in thickets or underwater in weed beds. Their limited intelligence makes them smart enough to supplement hunting by tending available food like mosses or oysters by clearing away predators. Sometimes, psionically powerful beings will capture and employ them as guardians.

entries.name: Ooze Nature
entries: An ooze doesn't require air or sleep, even if its additional form would seem to need both.

Penanggalans result from dark sacrifices meant to stave off the torments of the next life. The right ritual rewards the suppliant with undeath. In this way, a servant has time to collect more souls to pay off a debt or gain status with its fiendish master.

A blood-drinking undead creature of great power and horrifying appearance, the penanggalan masquerades as a one of the living during the day, typically resembling and acting as it once was. In this form, it may act cordial, but it is soulless and incapable of genuine warmth. Any display of affection will likely infurate this horror and encourage it to target the offender the next night.

entries.name: Night Terror
entries: As soon as night falls, the masquerading undead assumes its true form. Its body goes limp, its head detaches and then rises into the air. It's eyes glow faintly as it flies off in search of a victim to feast upon. Adding to the horror, the creature's entrails hang from the head's base, slick with acidic poison. As it flies, it sometimes whispers the vile secrets, hellish curses and debasing torments that only this abomination would know.

entries.name: Death to the Defenseless
entries: When a suitable victim is found, the penanggalan will fly through open windows or melt into a disgusting ooze to crawl in through small gaps. It then charms sleeping prey, and uses its fang-filled mouth to make several, small punctures in a hard to notice spot. It quietly feasts on the victim's blood. (The penanggalan rarely attacks someone that's awake, only if its body or lair are threatened.) If the victim survives a feeding, he or she will remember nothing, only disturbingly ominous dreams.

To prevent such attacks, some have found that the penanggalan is warded off by thick vegetation, especially thorny plants. Vibrant vegetation is abhorant to the abomination, but it also slashes and snags it.

entries.name: Flesh-Craving Servants
entries: Many of a penanggalan's victims rise as simple ghouls -- bound to protect its lair and body as it hunts. But if the penanggalan is slain, remaining ghouls are released. The first to drink the blood of an innocent is given the chance to become a penanggalan with the other ghouls as servants. As a result, adventurers that fail to do their research and take precautions could face the same foe all over again.

entries.name: Vital Corpse
entries: Penanggalans are understandably secretive creatures who make their lairs in mines, ruins, crypts, underground dungeons, or other abandoned buildings or structures. Their lairs are always protected by traps and ghoul servitors to kill or frighten off intruders. Inside a lair, its headless body appears to be merely a well-preserved, decapitated corpse. However, any that have the nerve to examine the neck will see that the body cavity is hollow and dessicated. If not already alerted by traps, the penanggalan will "know" when intruders reach its body. This is the only occasion when it'll attempt to destroy a conscious enemy.

Near the body, there is always a basin filled with an herbinfused vinegar. When the head returns, it must soak its entrails in the bath to shrink them enough to fit back inside its body and restore its dissimulating appearance. If sunlight strikes a penanggalan's head when it is separated from the body, the head will be paralyzed and fall helplessly to the ground. If not reunited within a few hours after sunrise, head and body will rapidly rot away. Therefore, a penanggalan will always rush to return to its lair well before dawn.

entries.name: Living Imposter
entries: When the head and body are joined, detect evil and good, divine sense and similar magics will not reveal its undead nature. Similarly, the 'living form' is immune and does not react to holy symbols and undead turning. The body is as it was in life, with none of the penangugalan's undead traits. However, despite the versimilitude of life, the head maintains all of its damage resistance, damage immunities and condition immunities and is unaffected by damage to the body.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A penanggalan doesn't require air, food, drink or sleep.

The thirsting death is a malevolent, vaporous creature that feeds on the blood of the living. Its pale gray or white form and the indistinct humanoid shape at its center are difficult to distinguish from fog or clouds.

entries.name: In the Shadows
entries: The secretive thirsting death dwells wherever fog and pockets of darkness prevail, but prefers bogs and marshes. Lairs are usually in caves, crevaces or areas with thick underbrush blocking the sun.

Extemely reticent, it is, however, still capable of speech. Its voice is a series of barely audible whispers, no louder than a soft breeze. Its words are reserved for making alliances, preferably ones that provide a steady supply of victims.

entries.name: Cold and Calculated
entries: It typically consumes one victim per week. Intelligent and cautious, it uses treasure it collects to lure victims, preferably solitary. If several are present, the thirsting death tries to pick off the guard while the rest sleep.
The thirsting death is capable of lifting any object it surrounds, including dead victims. This allows it to conceal its presence by disposing of corpses in its lair or a deep bog.

entries.name: True Colors
entries: When it feeds, the vapor takes on an easily noticed wine-colored hue. At the same time, the center of the cloud darkens and takes on a much more solid, skeleton-like form. If a thirsting death dies, it immediately dissipates while any undigested blood rains down in a grotesque shower.

The thirsting death's traits have led sages to theorize that it is actually the result of the death or partial destruction of a vampire. Others believer that, when a vampire is created, its soul is reborn elsewhere as a crimson death. Some legends says that the vampire may be restored to normal life if it is rejoined with its thirsting death counterpart.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A thirsting death doesn't require air, food, drink or sleep.

An undying heresy is the undead spirit of an evil priest or sage who died with at least one important, and usually contentious, doctrinal question unresolved. Its spectral form is frozen by its evil contemplations, devoting all of its energy to solving the mystery. It takes no interest in its surroundings. Nothing moves or rouses it, only destruction.

entries.name: Lost in Thought
entries: The undying heresy is only found in isolated locations, especially the ruins of temples, libraries, monasteries or other places of learning. It appears as a seated, insubstantial figure swathed in slate-colored robes. Orbiting it are tiny, wispy creatures known as anticreeds. They look similar, but sport spindly, wicked claws. These acrimonious creatures eagerly attack the living and are actually the heresy's evil thoughts. They dwell within the heresy's aura, which grows, spreading outward every century.

entries.name: Sobering Thought
entries: Certain theologians speculate that powerful evil clerics who, at death, become undying heresies may have been attempting to become demigods. It is feared that after at least 1,000 years, a few manage to resolve their philosophical dilemmas, leading them to transcend the material world and become profoundly evil, immortal beings. Sages urge those who discover a heresy to destroy it immediately, in case the frightening theory has merit.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A undying heresy and its anticreeds don't require air, food, drink or sleep.
